articles.headline: In Grocery Stores, the Perimeters Take Center Stage
articles.snippet: As sales droop in the staid center aisles full of shelf-stable products, grocers are focusing on more glamorous areas like the deli, bakery and produce sections.
articles.abstract: As sales droop in the staid center aisles full of shelf-stable products, grocers are focusing on more glamorous areas like the deli, bakery and produce sections.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAGAN, Minn. — The doors of the Cub Foods grocery store in this middle-class suburban city open onto piles of picture-perfect peaches and nectarines nestled next to jewel-toned plums and grapes.

articles.headline: Italy Wrestles With Rewriting Its Stifling Labor Laws
articles.snippet: Pallini, the maker of Sambuca liqueur, would like to expand, but like many Italian companies it fears that state-imposed labor costs could strangle it if the economy worsens.
articles.abstract: Pallini, the maker of Sambuca liqueur, would like to expand, but like many Italian companies it fears that state-imposed labor costs could strangle it if the economy worsens.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Micaela Pallini stood amid the heady perfume of anise-scented sambuca in the Roman distillery run by her family for five generations and pointed to a gleaming row of bottles rolling off a packaging line.

articles.headline: U.S. Goldman Disclosure a Rare Break in Secrecy
articles.snippet: After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.
articles.abstract: After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.

articles.headline: Card Swipes in Church Make Giving Easier
articles.snippet: Most religious institutions are better at collecting money than they used to be, by accepting donations via credit card or electronically pulling money from people’s bank accounts.
articles.abstract: Most religious institutions are better at collecting money than they used to be, by accepting donations via credit card or electronically pulling money from people’s bank accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: For anyone who spends time pondering the cost of keeping the lights on and the staff paid at their houses of worship, the Mormon tithing slip has a sort of utilitarian beauty.

articles.headline: Standard Chartered Case Casts a Chill Over Banks
articles.snippet: Global banks are worried that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, federal authorities said.
articles.abstract: Global banks are worried that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, federal authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Money laundering accusations leveled against a British bank by New York’s top banking regulator are causing global banks to worry that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, according to federal authorities with knowledge of the concerns.

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Hezbollah of Aiding Syria’s Crackdown
articles.snippet: The United States said the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has trained and advised government forces inside Syria and has helped to expel opposition fighters from within the country.
articles.abstract: The United States said the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has trained and advised government forces inside Syria and has helped to expel opposition fighters from within the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States accused the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah on Friday of deep involvement in the Syrian government’s violent campaign to crush the uprising there, asserting that Hezbollah has trained and advised government forces inside Syria and has helped to expel opposition fighters from areas within the country.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Romney to Announce Running Mate Saturday
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice-presidential candidate in Norfolk, Va., aboard the U.S.S. Wisconsin, and several signs were pointing toward Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice-presidential candidate in Norfolk, Va., aboard the U.S.S. Wisconsin, and several signs were pointing toward Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin.
articles.lead_paragraph: 1:17 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice-presidential candidate on Saturday in Norfolk, Va., with several signs pointing toward Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin emerging as the leading candidate for the position.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefront
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate Saturday in Norfolk, Va., making a selection that will intensify the campaign debate on the size and role of government.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate Saturday in Norfolk, Va., making a selection that will intensify the campaign debate on the size and role of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney introduced Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate on Saturday at a spirited rally in Norfolk, Va., bringing to his side one of the party’s young conservative leaders in a move that altered the contours of the campaign and sharpened the choice facing the voters in November.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Elevating Ryan, and His Budget Details
articles.snippet: To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail in his plan to reduce the nation’s debt. Tapping the architect of the House Republican budget plan changes that.
articles.abstract: To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail in his plan to reduce the nation’s debt. Tapping the architect of the House Republican budget plan changes that.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To date, Mitt Romney has been criticized for a lack of detail behind his promise to reduce the nation’s rising debt through sweeping spending cuts and tax changes, but he has also been politically insulated by it.

articles.headline: In Olympic Park, a Deluge From Our Sponsors
articles.snippet: Commercial messages are generally shunned at the main site of the London Games. But pavilions erected by corporate sponsors are loud exceptions.
articles.abstract: Commercial messages are generally shunned at the main site of the London Games. But pavilions erected by corporate sponsors are loud exceptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON

articles.headline: Breaking a Buck, Maybe, but Not Taxpayers’ Backs
articles.snippet: Late this month, the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to vote on a plan to make money market funds keep enough capital to endure a future run.
articles.abstract: Late this month, the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to vote on a plan to make money market funds keep enough capital to endure a future run.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARK Aug. 29 on your calendar. It’s the day all of us could end up on the hook for a big future bailout.

articles.headline: A Mutual Fund Master, Too Worried to Rest
articles.snippet: At 83, John Bogle, the founder of Vanguard, says he’s never seen a market as treacherous as this one. But he still sees buying and holding index funds as the best option.
articles.abstract: At 83, John Bogle, the founder of Vanguard, says he’s never seen a market as treacherous as this one. But he still sees buying and holding index funds as the best option.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANGUARD, the penny-pinching mutual fund company founded by John C. Bogle, has become a colossus. Its index funds — once derided for not even trying to beat the market — are now the industry standard.

articles.headline: After Sinai Attack, U.S. and Egypt Step Up Talks on Security
articles.snippet: Concerned about a security vacuum in the Sinai region, officials in the United States and Egypt are discussing American aid that would include equipment, training and surveillance.
articles.abstract: Concerned about a security vacuum in the Sinai region, officials in the United States and Egypt are discussing American aid that would include equipment, training and surveillance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the wake of the attack that killed 16 Egyptian soldiers near the border with Israel last Sunday, the United States and Egypt are negotiating a package of assistance to address what administration officials described as a worsening security vacuum in the Sinai Peninsula.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Racial Profiling Rife at Airport, U.S. Officers Say
articles.snippet: Officers in an airport program intended to spot telltale mannerisms of potential terrorists say the operation has become a magnet for racial profiling.
articles.abstract: Officers in an airport program intended to spot telltale mannerisms of potential terrorists say the operation has become a magnet for racial profiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — More than 30 federal officers in an airport program intended to spot telltale mannerisms of potential terrorists say the operation has become a magnet for racial profiling, targeting not only Middle Easterners but also blacks, Hispanics and other minorities.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: In Upheaval for Egypt, Morsi Forces Out Military Chiefs
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi ousted his powerful defense minister, the army chief of staff and several senior generals, seeming for the moment to reclaim power the military had seized.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi ousted his powerful defense minister, the army chief of staff and several senior generals, seeming for the moment to reclaim power the military had seized.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt forced the retirement on Sunday of his powerful defense minister, the army chief of staff and other senior generals, moving more aggressively than ever before to reclaim political power that the military had seized since the fall of Hosni Mubarak last year.

articles.headline: Both Sides Focus on the Republican Ticket’s New Face
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney sought to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his vice-presidential choice without having to defend all of Representative Paul D. Ryan’s positions.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney sought to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his vice-presidential choice without having to defend all of Representative Paul D. Ryan’s positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Democrats moved aggressively on Sunday to wrap Mitt Romney in the politically charged details of budget-cutting proposals championed by his new running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, as Mr. Romney sought to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his choice without having to defend every element of Mr. Ryan’s positions.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: A Steep Climb Back for Facebook’s Stock
articles.snippet: In a new test for the company’s stock, over 1.6 billion shares will be eligible to come on the market in several waves when a number of shareholders are allowed to sell.
articles.abstract: In a new test for the company’s stock, over 1.6 billion shares will be eligible to come on the market in several waves when a number of shareholders are allowed to sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Facebook spring is over. The dog days of August have taken hold.

articles.headline: MundoFox to Enter the Latino TV Market
articles.snippet: With its debut on Monday, MundoFox, a partnership between Fox and a Colombian television company, will enter a market long dominated by Univision and Telemundo.
articles.abstract: With its debut on Monday, MundoFox, a partnership between Fox and a Colombian television company, will enter a market long dominated by Univision and Telemundo.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The correspondents were on camera and on location in Mexico City, Washington and Los Angeles. Rolando Nichols, the lead anchor, listened intently to the receiver in his ear as he stood in front of the bright red walls of the news studio.

articles.headline: Wondering How Far Magazines Must Fall
articles.snippet: Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been tough, but the root of Newsweek’s continued losses lies in a changing marketplace.
articles.abstract: Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been tough, but the root of Newsweek’s continued losses lies in a changing marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been a tough racket. It takes a big staff working on punishing deadlines to aggregate the flurry of news, put some learned topspin on it and package it for readers. But that job now belongs to the Web and takes place in real time, not a week later.

articles.headline: NBC Banks on Olympics as Springboard for New Shows
articles.snippet: In spite of the millions watching the Games on any given night, history suggests that exposure during the Olympics does not necessarily drive viewers to new shows.
articles.abstract: In spite of the millions watching the Games on any given night, history suggests that exposure during the Olympics does not necessarily drive viewers to new shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Olympics have cast a spell over NBC for the last two weeks, bestowing the gift of flight on a network long stuck in ratings mud. But like Wile E. Coyote suddenly discovering his jet pack has run out of fuel, a vertiginous plunge looms.

articles.headline: Libor Case Energizes a Wall Street Watchdog
articles.snippet: The Barclays rate-manipulation case has thrust Gary Gensler — and his once-obscure agency, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission — into the spotlight.
articles.abstract: The Barclays rate-manipulation case has thrust Gary Gensler — and his once-obscure agency, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission — into the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after he arrived in Washington in 2009, Gary Gensler knew he had a big case.

articles.headline: Problems Riddle Moves to Collect Credit Card Debt
articles.snippet: Judges said that big lenders were using inaccurate or incomplete records to go after consumers, including some who had already paid their debts.
articles.abstract: Judges said that big lenders were using inaccurate or incomplete records to go after consumers, including some who had already paid their debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The same problems that plagued the foreclosure process — and prompted a multibillion-dollar settlement with big banks — are now emerging in the debt collection practices of credit card companies.

articles.headline: Korea Policing the Net. Twist? It’s South Korea.
articles.snippet: As one of the world’s most wired societies, South Korea has embraced the Web, but a recent crackdown on Internet freedom has drawn accusations of censorship.
articles.abstract: As one of the world’s most wired societies, South Korea has embraced the Web, but a recent crackdown on Internet freedom has drawn accusations of censorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A government critic who called the president a curse word on his Twitter account found it blocked. An activist whose Twitter posting likened officials to pirates for approving a controversial naval base was   accused by the navy of criminal defamation. And a judge who wrote that the president (“His Highness”) was out to “screw” Internet users who challenged his authority was fired in what was widely seen as retaliation.

articles.headline: Motorola Set for Big Cuts as Google Reinvents It
articles.snippet: The cuts are the first step in Google’s plan to reinvent the company that it bought in May, and to shore up its Android mobile business and expand beyond search and software.
articles.abstract: The cuts are the first step in Google’s plan to reinvent the company that it bought in May, and to shore up its Android mobile business and expand beyond search and software.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Motorola Mobility, the ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, told employees Sunday that it would lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide.

articles.headline: Conservative Star’s Small-Town Roots
articles.snippet: After his father died, Paul D. Ryan formed a self-reliance that would shape his worldview and one day capture the imagination of Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: After his father died, Paul D. Ryan formed a self-reliance that would shape his worldview and one day capture the imagination of Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan’s childhood home here was not overtly partisan. His parents were enthusiastic supporters of Representative Les Aspin, a Democrat, yet adored President Ronald Reagan from their glimpses of him on the evening news. But the death of his father when Mr. Ryan was only 16 punctured his life of math tests and bike riding, and in that fissure, the seeds of his worldview were planted.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer, Jim Rutenberg, Mike McIntire and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
